subject: Economics
title: Sweatshops: The Uncomfortable Economics of Poor Options
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Sweatshops: The Uncomfortable Economics of Poor Options.

hook.text: A factory in Vietnam pays $2/hour. Americans call it exploitation.

buildup.text: Sweatshops offer terrible conditions by Western standards â€” long hours, low pay, unsafe buildings.

discovery.text: Paul Krugman argued that sweatshops, while deplorable, are a stage of development every rich country passed through.

twist.text: When boycotts closed Bangladeshi factories in the 1990s, children who lost factory jobs didn't go to school.

climax.text: Sweatshops are economics' most uncomfortable truth: the best available option for the poor can still be terrible.

punchline.text: The tragedy of sweatshops is not that they exist.

quiz.question: What happened when boycotts closed Bangladeshi garment factories in the 1990s?
options: Displaced child workers often ended up in worse situations including prostitution rather than school
